text:
<@ULJBEFSJJ> that's a good suggestion, thank you! The challenge I have with that is that I actually already have a UX Designer on the Marketing team (yes.... slightly odd set-up I know...a hire from before my time). Our UX designer is actually responsible for (and great at!) all the back-end coding, but he is not a creative, and so he doesn't have much to work with in terms of creative assets. That's the gap we're trying to fill (along with overall brand identity of course).
<@U01KYJVARBP>'s question is also interesting, and something I've been asked a couple of times and struggled to put my finger on how to answer. As I'm writing this I'm wondering if it's possibly *because* we already have a UXer in place that I may be struggling to fill the design role. Naturally, with the UXer in place, I've tried to create a clear boundary in terms of designing the Designer job spec to focus on the creative stuff. But this means the profile of applicants tends to be coming from a softer creative side, lots of applicants with experience in B2C, print and experiential stuff; very few with an understanding of B2B software sales trajectories and how buyers behave online. I had web page mock-ups submitted that looked fantastic, but like billboards or posters, if you understand what I mean. I don't expect a designer to understand the marketing stuff at a detailed level but there are certain page design frameworks and best practices that help website visitors instantly understand 'ah, it's a software platform'. If that makes any sense :sweat_smile:

text: Question: Who are some of your favorite up and coming SaaS companies?

elements.text: Question: Who are some of your favorite up and coming SaaS companies?

text: These *don't* have to be in the world of marketing, B2B, etc!

elements.text: have to be in the world of marketing, B2B, etc!

text:
I'll hype one of my clients. They're based out of my hometown (Halifax, NS) and are helping the janitorial world catch up to the technological future! Web app for managers, mobile app for cleaners/onsite staff.

Operational coordination tailored to the business. Owned, founded by a former cleaning business operator.

<https://www.sweptworks.com/>

attachments.service_name: Swept – Trusted Janitorial Software for Cleaning Companies
attachments.title: Swept: Janitorial Software, Time Tracking, Scheduling, Inspection
attachments.text: Trusted Janitorial Software that Saves Commercial Cleaning Companies Time & Money. Smart, simple design: time tracking, scheduling, inspection, and more.

text:
Are you allowed to hype your own company? I’m not normally a “Company man” but I’m pretty invested in my new place.

<http://Catalyst.io|Catalyst.io> has the most unique marketing plan in our space. Memes, value-rich content, and really oddball stuff that is still relevant to customers. AND the product itself is making waves in the CS industry.
